subject: RE: [junit] Beginner
msgSnippet: ... And once you learn the basics, and if you find that you are working on a project that does not already have tests, I highly recommend Working Effectively
messageBody:
... And once you learn the basics, and if you find that you are working
on a project that does not already have tests, I highly recommend
"Working Effectively With Legacy Code" by Michael Feathers on Prentice
Hall press. The book does a great job of showing some real-world
scenarios for how to add tests to code that wasn't designed for testing,
and you learn more about how to make testable code from the start.



Daniel Wellman

U.S. Trust

Ph: (201) 533-6157

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Simon Chappell
Sent: Friday, July 15, 2005 2:30 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Beginner



Priyanka,

Welcome to the wonderful world of JUnit.

There are many useful websites for the JUnit user, but perhaps the two
main ones are http://junit.org/ and http://google.com/.
<http://google.com/> The JUnit site
maintains alot of useful information and links to other resources.
Google is useful when there's something you need, but don't know what
it is. Just type a description in, press enter and see how much help
it can be. I've found quite a few useful things that way.

As far as books are concerned, I recommend Pragmatic Unit Testing by
Hunt and Thomas for beginners. JUnit recipies by Rainsberger is good
once you're past the basics.

I hope that this helps.

Simon
